The instructor and scholars from different universities will also be invited to present their latest research. Topical areas will include Operations Supply Chain Strategy, Total Quality Management, Service Operations Management, Innovation and New Product Development, Lean Thinking, Business Process Improvement/Innovation, Relationship Management and Supply Chain Integration, Supply Chain/Logistics Network Design and other topics.
outcome: 1. Familiarize the topics chosen by the course instructor and the related literature and research development 2. Understand the related concepts and methodologies 3. Able to apply the methods and techniques to identify and solve research problems

title: Data Mining for Managers
requirements: For student in MSc Business Analytics
description: This course emphasizes on the applications of data mining techniques in business problems from managerial perspectives. Business applications such as customer relationship management and financial analysis will be discussed throughout the course. Some basic data mining techniques will also be explained for illustration purposes. They include clustering, market basket analysis, data warehouse, and neural networks.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: (1) understand organizations' need for data mining; (2) understand managerial decision-making processes; (3) understand various algorithms of data mining; (4) develop self-learning in the area beyond the topics covered by this course; (5) provide hands on experience by using data mining application (e.g. SAS Enterprise Miner); (6) know how to apply the data mining application to solve the real problems.
syllabus: Week 1: Introduction Week 2: Business Issues Week 3: Business Intelligence Week 4: Data Mining Concepts Week 5: Data Pre-processing, Visualization and Exploratory Analysis Week 6: Decision Trees Model  Week 7: Lab 1: Excel-Based Data Mining Tool Week 8: Classification  Week 9: Lab 2: SAS Enterprise Miner Week 10: Clustering Week 11: Lab 3: SAS Enterprise Miner Week 12: Neural Network Explanation Week 13: Lab 4: Excel-Based Data Mining Tool Week 14: Project Presentation
required_readings: Data Mining using SAS Enterprise Miner, R. Matignon (Wiley) Discovering Knowledge in Data: An Introduction to Data Mining, Daniel T. Larose (Wiley) Business Intelligence: Data Mining and Optimization for Decision Making, Carlo Vercellis (Wiley)

title: Economic Analytics
requirements: For students in MSc Business Analytics
description: This course is about applying economic models with data to deal with corporate decisions and strategies. The art and science of economic modeling for this purpose makes use of the principles and the tools derived from the studies of information economics, games, industrial organization and the related fields. The course is conducted in a variety of formats including lectures, cases studies and other activities. Operation and strategic issues covered in the course include setting prices, designing contracts, managing firm boundaries, controlling strategic information, analyzing entry and exit, and formulating competitive strategy.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  (1) master important economic relationships that determine success in a business environment; (2) make use of a number of tools, including decision tree analysis, value-added analysis, five-force analysis, competitive market analysis and game-theoretic analysis, in addressing strategic and decision problems; (3) use Excel to incorporate data into an analytical framework;  (4) explore implications and limitations from the analytical framework; (5) communicate and interact with non-specialists to discuss the issues involved and the pros and cons of a prescribed decisions from the analysis.

title: Risk and Operations Analytics
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
description: This course introduces the analysis of key issues related to the design and management of business operations using quantitative tools such as linear, integer, and non-linear programming, regression, and statistical analysis. It covers important topics such as revenue management and dynamic pricing, inventory theory, production control and scheduling, and risk management in supply chains, among others, and uses mathematical modeling, spreadsheet analysis, case studies, and simulation to deliver materials. The course introduces Monte Carlo simulations with Excel and Crystal Ball, focusing on their applications in solving business operations problems.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: (1) understand that risk and operations management plays a critical role in a business and how it contributes to the success of the business; (2) utilize quantitative tools, including linear, integer, and non-linear programming, regression, statistical analysis, and simulation, to model and analyze business problems; (3) derive key trade-offs involved in managing business operations with the aid of data and analytics; (4) speak the language of risk and operations management in communicating and interacting with non-specialists and discussing related issues.

title: Web Analytics and Intelligence
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
description: The course focuses on the collection, analysis, and use of web data for business intelligence. Topics covered include web analytics concepts, web analytics technologies and techniques, visitor activity analysis methods, and web intelligence fundamentals. The course also evaluates practical, real-work analysis cases to demonstrate the strategic uses of web analytics for business intelligence and proper application of analytics techniques for online data optimization.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  (1) master the techniques and tools to track, collect, measure, report, and analyze quantitative Internet data to optimize websites and web marketing initiatives; (2) design strategies to optimize web operation and improve online performance; (3) apply web analytics skills and practices to solve business problems, enhance business decisions, and improve business intelligence; and (4) align web strategy to organizational IT and business strategies for business performance and competitiveness.
syllabus: The course covers the following topics: • Fundamentals of web analytics • Big data and small data: different types of intelligence  • Website success measures: site goals, key performance indicators, and key metrics • Tools and techniques of Web analytics: focus on learning the use of Google Analytics • Website performance analysis: traffic analysis and search and keyword analysis • Strategic application of online data to drive website improvement • Leveraging digital analytics effectively • Emerging analytics: social, mobile, and video
recommended_readings: Clifton, B. Advanced Metrics with Google Analytics, 3rd edition, Wiley Publishing, Inc., 2012.  Isson, J. P. and Harriot, J. Win with Advanced Business Analytics: Creating Business Values from Your Data, Wiley and SAS, 2012.  Kaushik, A. Web Analytics 2.0, Wiley Publishing, Inc., 2010.  Russell, M.A. Mining the Social Web: Analyzing Data from Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and Other Social Media Sites. O'Reilly Meida, Inc., 2011.

title: Business Process Analysis and Simulation
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
description: This course introduces knowledge used to model and analyze business processes, with an emphasis on quantitative skills. A simulation package will be introduced and will be utilized to evaluate business process performance and to facilitate the decision making on business process improvement. The knowledge learnt from the course can equip students with scientific competence and help them solve practical problems in various settings related to business process management.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  (1) understand fundamental relationship of business processes;  (2) use scientific tools to model and analyze business processes and deliver managerial insights based on the analysis; (3) have the ability to construct business process simulation models and use the models to facilitate decision makings on business process improvement; (4) speak the language of business process management in communicating and interacting with non-specialists and discussing related issues.

title: Selected Topics of Information and Technology Management
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
description: This course is designed to investigate and to discuss selected topics of current interests in the area of information and technology management.
outcome: To broaden students’ perspective on the contemporary issues in current information and technology management.

title: Fintech and Its Applications
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
description: Advance in information technology has already started a revolution in the financial industry. Every part of the financial service system is affected, from daily payment to long-term investment, from efficiency gain to logic transformation. The pace of change is fast. Too fast to catch, yet too critical to miss. Institutions which can leverage the new technologies gain superior market insights, create new business models, and will become the future leaders of the financial service industry. Individuals who can understand and work with FinTech open new gates for investment and career development. This course introduces FinTech and examines opportunities and challenges. It seeks to equip students with both a deep and practical understanding of emerging technology in the FinTech arena as well as the necessary coding skills to tackle future demand. We are going to cover topics such as the fundamentals of the financial service system, technology disruption, data management and visualization, financial data mining (Python), quantitative trading and artificial intelligence, crowdfunding, blockchain technology, and RegTech.Applications on practical FinTech problems are emphasized with case discussions and programming assignments. While we will work with computer codes, this course does NOT assume any programming background from students.
outcome: Through the learning of this course, students should be able to achieve the following goals: 1. Understand the basic concepts in FinTech, for example, disruptive innovation, business analytics, big data, quantitative trading, statistical arbitrage, unstructured data, text mining, deep learning, crowdfunding, peer-to-peer network, blockchain, regulatory sandbox, etc. 2. Explain the factors that determine the success and failure of IT-supported business initiatives in Finance. 3. Explain the factors that determine the performance of a quantitative trading model. 4. Discuss the opportunities and challenges for specific innovative FinTech applications. 5. Read and write simple programs to implement data visualization, trading algorithms, text-mining techniques, blockchain applications, etc.
syllabus: The course contains the following modules. (Tentative) In group discussions, the lecturer will lead student groups in discussing cases, programming, or analyzing projects.   Module 1 Course Overview - The FinTech revolution - Technology disruption and business model innovation - The future of financial market and financial services - Group Discussion: Mobile payment  Module 2 Financial Services System - Fundamentals of financial services - Banking and risk management - Trading and Investment - Data and data management  Module 3 Financial Programming I - Statistics recap - Python introduction - Group Discussion: As simple as Python  Module 4 Analytics and the Art of Visualization - Working with financial data - Big data and analytics in finance - Visualization tools - Group Discussion: Designing a dashboard  Module 5 Smart Alpha - Big data Alpha model - Alpha model consideration - Big data factors from text and other unstructured data - Algo trading basics - Machine learning algorithm - AI and Deep Learning - Robo-advisor in asset management - Group Discussion: Programming for investment professionals  Module 6 Blockchain - Democratizing finance - Crowdfunding and financial inclusion - Blockchain technology - The token economy - Group Discussion: ICO and blockchain project evaluation  Module 7 Fintech for Consumers - Smart service delivery systems - Mass customization in finance - RegTech - Emerging trend in consumer finance

title: Advanced Information Systems Practicum
requirements: For students in MSc Info & Technology Mgt
description: This course bridges the gap between classroom and real world. It requires students to complete a real-world information systems project, in collaboration with a company or organization. Students are required to form a project team, under the joint supervision of a teacher and an executive of the sponsoring company.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: (1) understand the most current IT issues/management/trend in the commercial sector; (2) understand how real-world projects are managed and executed in a group setting; (3) improve their knowledge of real-world project development; (4) develop the skills (communication and leadership) required to complete IT projects.
syllabus: - Project management - Business model in real world - Others (depending on the project topic)
required_readings: Readings vary, depending on student's selected project. The company supervisor may assign several internal documents or reports for students to read so that they can understand and complete their project.
recommended_readings: Students have to search the library or internet to retrieve relevant documents, articles, reports to complete their project.

title: Data Communication and Networking
requirements: For students in MSc in Information & Technology Management
description: This course discusses the concepts and principles of data communications and computer networks. It prepares students to make intelligent and informed decisions about moving voice, data, image and video between locations securely, by making them aware of the benefits, drawbacks, and effects related to various data communication technologies. Students will also learn how to make policy, design, and installation decisions related to planning and implementing data communication and network applications.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to:  (1) understand the fundamental concepts of data communication and computer networking;  (2) master the application and management of data communications and networking in business applications;  (3) formulate the policies and governance of an organization’s IT infrastructure, networks, and business operating environment; and  (4) make intelligent, reasonable, thoughtful, and accurate decisions about the optimal configuration, installation, security and operation of a data communication network.
syllabus: Possible topics include: • Data transmission (such as analog and digital signals, data encoding techniques, error control, flow control, and multiplexing) • Internet operations, including TCP/IP • Local area network architecture and infrastructure • Wide area network technology, protocols, and services • Wireless local and wide area networks • Network security
required_readings: [TBC]
recommended_readings: • Stallings, W. and Case, T. Business Data Communications. 7th Edition, Pearson, 2012. • Fitzgerald, Dennis, and Durcikova. Business Data Communications and Networking, 12th Edition, Wiley, 2015.

title: Technology Startup-From Idea to Reality
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
description: This is a practical course on entrepreneurial business management as a living skill to start, build and grow a technology enterprise. Learn by creating a new business based on the know-how and wisdom from Silicon Valley to Asia, including evaluating business opportunities, innovation, generating business model, business plan, team building, competition analysis, IP, financing, growth, Silicon Valley and Asian business culture.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: 1. Understand the basic criteria for identifying a real business opportunity; 2. Understand the process of creating a start-up company; 3. Know the nuts and bolts of running a startup and the issues with it; 4. Apply the entrepreneurial process to many different activities.

title: IT Law for Executives
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management
description: Information technology becomes more and more important in our business sector. Issues relating to information technology and law, such as privacy and location surveillance, digital signature, copyright, outsourcing, anti-competition and contracts are essential to our daily life. This course examines the link between IT law and business operations; it offers a clear picture to students who are at executive level with no related legal background. Topics will include introduction of the Hong Kong Legal System; Contract Law; Torts Law; internet impact on legal systems; IT and IP Laws in business operations and the latest Competition Ordinance.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  (1) understand the legal system in Hong Kong;  (2) have a sufficient understanding of contract law and tort law and IT law to handle the common situations arising in the business world; (3) avoid the legal traps in their daily personal and business encounters; (4) obtain a sufficient knowledge as to various aspects on the above from a PRC perspective.

title: Selected Topics of Business Analytics
requirements: For students in MSc Business Analytics
description: This course is designed to investigate and to discuss selected topics of current interests in the area of business analytics.

title: Advanced Business Analytics Practicum
requirements: For students in MSc Business Analytics
description: This course bridges the gap between classroom and real world. It requires students to complete a real-world business analytics project, in collaboration with a company or organization. Students are required to form a project team, under the joint supervision of a teacher and an executive of the sponsoring company.

title: Artificial Intelligence for Business
requirements: For students in MSc Business Analytics; or MSc Information & Technology Management
description: This course provides a holistic overview of artificial intelligence (AI) models, as well as their mathematical and programming background. It covers, together with others, commonly used machine learning methods such as Bayes classifiers, decision tree, random forest, boosting, support vector machine, and neural network. This course emphasizes on understanding the intuition behind the methods and on applying them to business practices. It helps build hands-on experiences by using business data and R, an analytics software package. Previous coding knowledge will be needed for this course, and a decent familiarity with basic quantitative content (such as algebra and statistics) will also be required.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: (1) understand that artificial intelligence can play an important role in business practice and how it can improve the performance of the business practice; (2) utilize some commonly used machine learning methods, including Bayes classifiers, decision tree, random forest, boosting, support vector machine, and neural network, to analyze business data; (3) implement the machine learning methods with R; (4) speak the language of machine learning and artificial intelligence in communicating and interacting with non-specialists and discussing related issues.

title: Business Forecasting
requirements: For students in MSc Business Analytics
description: This course provides students with principles and methods in forecasting for managerial planning. Major topics include multiple regression analysis, time series analysis with emphasis on smoothing techniques, decomposition methods, and Box-Jenkins procedures and indicator forecasting. Applications of the methods to both short-term and long-term forecasting to business, industries and national business trends are also emphasized.

title: Project Management
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MSc Business Analytics
description: This course covers the management of projects. A major focus is on how to manage various projects to successful completion within the constraints of resources and time. Included in the contents are the frameworks for proposal writing and planning, monitoring and controlling, and performance evaluation. Various project management techniques are covered including PERT/CPM and project appraisal. Case studies and field projects as well as lectures will be used as teaching methods.
outcome: On completion of this course students should be able to:  • demonstrate a basic understanding of the theories, concepts and principles of project management with reference to the Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) published by PMI • articulate the essential components of the project management initiating and planning process, and appreciate the application of project management and organisational behaviour theories in managing projects
syllabus: • project management principles & the Project Management Institute (PMI) framework covering TEN Knowledge Areas including integration, scope, time, cost, quality, HR, communications, risk, procurement and stakeholder management
required_readings: Text Book: Kathy Schwalbe, “Managing Information Technology Projects”, 7th Ed 2012
recommended_readings: Reference Book: Project Management Institute (USA), “A guide to project management body of knowledge”. 5th Edition (PMI USA), 2012.

title: Database and Big Data Management
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
description: This course focuses on both business data and contemporary big data modeling and management. We will examine the different natures of data and big data, selection and representation as well as use of suitable methods and tools for storing and accessing them. Topics such as data integrity, DBMS, data warehousing, NoSQL and MapReduce are covered.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  (1) understand basic concepts and theories in data and big data management;  (2) analyze and model business data requirements and use DBMS for data management; (3) master NoSQL data management system; and (4) develop basic skills for querying and analyzing big data
syllabus: Possible syllabus - The concept of data integration and the database approach - Relational data model & normalization schema, integrity rules and implementation - Structured Query Language  - Semantic data modeling  - Databases and the Internet - Data warehousing & big data  - Capturing social media data & NoSQL

title: Information Systems Analysis and Auditing
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management
description: This course provides students with knowledge and experience of analyzing the essential aspects of information systems in the real world. Emphases will be placed on the object-oriented analysis techniques using the Unified Modeling Language. Various key business activities will be discussed. This course will also explain the importance of business IS controls in contemporary IT governance. A business framework for the management of enterprise IS will be investigated.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  (1) Describe the classification of information systems (2) Analyze various aspects of information systems using Unified Modeling Language (3) Understand the concepts of information systems controls (4) Identify the basic components in conducting information systems audit
syllabus: - Business information systems life cycle - Main components in feasibility study - IT cost estimation - Introduction to information system modeling - Analysis using Unified Modeling Language - Major components in IT Control - Brief introduction to the COBIT framework
recommended_readings: - Dull, R.B., Gelinas, U.J., & Wheeler, P.R. (2012). Accounting Information Systems: Foundations in Enterprise Risk Management, 9th Ed. Cengage Learning. - Fowler, M. (2004). UML Distilled - A Brief Guide to the Standard Object Modeling Language, 3rd Ed. Addison-Wesley.

title: Business Intelligence Techniques and Applications
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
description: This course emphasizes on the applications of business intelligence techniques in the era of big data. The techniques will include data preparation, dimensionality reduction, clustering, classification, market basket analysis, and performance evaluation. Business applications such as customer segmentation and financial analysis will be discussed throughout the course.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: (1) understand the basic classification of different business intelligence techniques. (2) explain the ideas and limitations of each major business intelligence technique. (3) analyze business data using existing software. (4) evaluate the performance of the techniques. (5) make business decisions by leveraging on big data.
syllabus: - Introduction of data, algorithms and related business applications - Concepts of data preparation - Dimensionality reduction & its applications - Clustering techniques using k-means and its variants - Classification techniques using logistic regression, decision trees and instance-based learning - Association rules  - Concepts of neural networks - Performance evaluation
recommended_readings: - Turban, E. et al. (2011). Business Intelligence: A Managerial Approach. Prentice Hall - Tan, et al. (2006). Introduction to Data Mining, Pearson Education (Addison Wesley).

title: Mobile and Web Applications Development
requirements: For students in MSc in Information & Technology Management
description: This course provides students with the basic knowledge to design and develop Android applications for mobile devices. Students will work directly with the Java programming language and the latest Android developer tools, with the goal of enabling students to produce fully functional prototypes independently. This course will also place some emphasis on developing web applications using JavaScript. The basic concepts of client server architecture and simple Java Server Pages (JSP) will also be introduced.

title: Cyber Security
requirements: For students in MSc in Information & Technology Management
description: This course provides an overview of the threats to networked organizations. Students will learn and understand the key issues associated with cyber space security, skills required to respond to security incidents, and knowledge needed to design security systems and protect security intrusions. Its coverage includes a variety of concepts and topics related to the securing of networked, cloud, and mobile processing environments.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to: (1) assess the current security landscape and the likely consequences of security failures; (2) apply the practices, technologies, and protocols of cyber security to secure business operations; (3) assess the security challenges in the virtual, cloud, and mobile processing environments; (4) understand the legal, ethical, and regulatory issues associated with cyber security policy development, implementation, and administration.
syllabus: Possible topics include: • Physical and system security (such as access control, user authentication, malicious software, and operating system security) • Network security (such as encryption, intrusion detection and prevention, and firewalls) • Security protocols and standards • Database and cloud computing security • Wireless security • Security management and planning  • Legal and ethical aspects of security
recommended_readings: • Conklin, W.A. and White, G. Principles of Computer Security, 4th Edition, McGraw Hill Education, 2016. • Whitman, W. and Mattord, H. Principles of Information Security, 4th Edition, Cengage, 2012. • Stallings, W. and Brown, L. Computer Security: Principles and Practices, 3rd Edition, Pearson, 2015.

title: Technology Field Study
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
description: This course consists of preparatory assignments in readings and a written study plan, followed by a five-day residential program to Silicon Valley, California or similar Science Parks in Asia. The course is concluded with a written report and an oral presentation. The goal in taking classroom sessions abroad is to expose our graduate students to a wide spectrum of issues related to IT business, which includes research and development, company culture, and ways to manage a technology company. The issues are highlighted through lectures or seminars by university professors, and visits to world class companies or research and development centres. Students will have chance to discuss with top executives from these companies. Through this course, students will be able to understand the strategies companies adopted, and solutions in tackling business issues.
outcome: 1. Students will recognize the reasons of the success of IT businesses in Silicon Valley or similar Science Parks 2. Students will be able to learn the strategies adopted by the firms we visited.

title: Supply Chain and Logistics Management
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Busienss Analytics
description: This course covers the concepts, insights, practical tools, and decision support systems for the effective management of the supply chain. This course will convey both the intuitions behind many key supply chain and logistics management concepts and to provide simple techniques that can be used to analyze various aspects of the supply chain and logistics management. The role of supply chain and logistics management in the age of eBusiness will be addressed. Through readings and case studies, we will identify the current and prospective supply chain practices.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  (1) understand the concepts and the insights of supply chain and logistics management; (2) analyze various aspects of supply chain and logistics management by using practical tools;  (3) address the role of supply chain and logistics management in eBusiness; (4) identify the current and prospective practices of supply chain and logistics management.

title: Strategy and Innovation Management
requirements: For students in EMBA (Chinese)
description: The aim of this course is to provide a solid grounding to students interested in managing various aspects of the innovation process and understanding it better from a policy perspective. The course is divided into two parts. Broadly, the first two-thirds of the course focuses more on analytic and strategic frameworks for managing innovation. This segment examines patterns of technological change and their impacts, planning for technological transitions, means for capturing economic benefits from innovation, and planning of innovation projects over time. The last third of the course examines more organizational issues involved in implementing strategies. These issues include management of teams and partnerships, learning within and across projects, the manager's role in forecasting and funding, directing and stopping innovation projects, technological entrepreneurship, and barriers to innovation. Case studies, both written and video-based, are used extensively to illustrate a range of technologies and the problems associated with developing them and bringing them to market.

title: Managing Supply Chains in China
requirements: For students in MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
description: This course is designed to expose students to the challenges and opportunities of managing supply chains in the dynamic environment of China. Students will be required to analyze and discuss a number of cases of companies operating in China. Through these case discussions and the summaries by the instructor, students will learn how to make strategic and operational decisions in supply chains related to China. They will also learn how Chinese culture, traditions, political, legal systems and logistics infrastructure influence supply chain decisions. More specifically, the objectives for the course are for students to:1. Understand the business environment in China and roles that China plays in global supply chains2. Comprehend Chinese Culture and Traditions and how they influence supply chain operations and decisions3. Make important decisions related to the choice of supply chain strategies, design and improvements of supply chain processes4. Learn how to select supply chain partners and manage supply chain relationships in the dynamic business environment of china

title: Enterprise Resource Planning
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management
description: Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) is an integrated information technology to manage company-wide business processes. The topics include two aspects: enterprise resource planning system and the ERP project implementation issues. This course will also introduce the evolution of ERP, concepts and application of ERP. The topics of enterprise systems will mainly brief on the core modules along the value chain such as product development, order fulfillment, production and others. Finally, the "ERP and beyond" will address how the latest developments of ERP be extended to fulfill the new demand of more enterprise initiatives. Students will be requested to work on a group project.
outcome: After completing the course, the students are expected to  1. comprehend the concept / theory of enterprise resource planning 2. be familiar with an enterprise system, particularly the ERP suite 3. understand the issues for an ERP implementation  4. apprehend the future trends of ERP

title: Independent Study
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics
description: Students will be assigned a research project guided and supervised by a course instructor. The course aims to further develop students’ capability and experience in undertaking research study. Upon completion, students are required to submit and present their research report.
outcome: Students should learn how to conduct an independent research project. After completing this course, students should have acquired the following professional skills to deal with research questions: (1) being familiar with relevant literature; (2) studying and applying proper research methodologies; (3) conducting data analysis and (4) improving presentation and report writing skills.

title: Thesis Research
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics
description: To monitor students’ progress in thesis and research.
outcome: The goal of this course is to monitor students’ progress in thesis and research. Upon completing this course, students will develop a skill to summarize the essential ingredients of a paper in a concise way, to develop an original research topic, and to empirically execute the idea using what they have learned in other seminar courses.
